description: From Late Latin tropicus (“of or pertaining to the solstice, as a noun, one of the tropics”), from Ancient Greek τροπικός (tropikós, “of or pertaining to a turn or change; or the solstice; or a trope or figure; tropic; tropical; etc.”), from τροπή (tropḗ, “turn; solstice; trope”).

adjectives.description: tropic (comparative more tropic, superlative most tropic)

entries.meaning: Of, or relating to the tropics; tropical.
(biochemistry, incomparable) Having the quality of indirectly inducing a biological or chemical change in a system or substrate.
examples: The binding of oxygen to hemoglobin is allosterically regulated by various tropic factors, such as BPG and acidity.

entries.meaning: Pertaining to, involving, or of the nature of a trope or tropes.
Either of the two parallels of latitude 23°27′ north and south of the equator; the farthest points at which the sun can be directly overhead; the boundaries of the torrid zone or tropics.
examples: For since on ev'ry Sea, on ev'ry Coast,
Your Men have been distress'd, your Navy tost,
Sev'n times the Sun has either Tropick view'd,
The Winter banishish'd, and the Spring renew'd.
